awd_titl_txt: 2020 NSF ENG CAREER Proposal Writing Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the organization of a National Science Foundation Directorate for Engineering 2020 Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) Proposal Writing Workshop. The workshop will be held in the Washington, D.C. area in the Spring of 2020, and it is expected that there will be about 300 attendees. The workshop will take place over one-and-a-half days and will include interactive sessions on good proposal writing practices, seminars by previous CAREER awardees, a mock CAREER proposal panel review, and a review session during which the attendees will have a chance to obtain feedback on project summaries of their own draft CAREER proposals. The attendees will also have an opportunity to interact with current NSF Program Directors both in one-on-one and in mock panel sessions. 

This workshop will help to prepare CAREER program eligible faculty for careers in education and research by giving them tools and skills of good proposal writing for submissions to the CAREER program as well as core NSF programs. The objectives of the workshop include training for junior faculty with an emphasis on women and underrepresented minorities in engineering. A special additional emphasis will be placed on encouraging CAREER program eligible faculty from non-"Research-1" institutions to apply for participation. The workshop will serve as an introduction to NSF for many new researchers. The workshop will help participants to clarify their research and education career plans and to understand the need to clearly articulate these plans to external reviewers. In addition, the workshop includes mock panel sessions to give participants the experience of simulated panel evaluation discussions. All of the content and experiences will help attendees enrich their skills for writing successful research proposals on impactful research that benefits societal needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The objective of the 2020 NSF ENG Directorate Workshop was to introduce junior faculty who are interested in submitting their NSF CAREER proposals to the Directorate for Engineering to the Program.   

The goal of the Workshop was to provide early-career faculty members the opportunity to improve their skills in proposal writing, interact with NSF program directors from different ENG divisions (CBET, ECCS, CMMI and EEC) and with recent NSF CAREER awardees. The Workshop was open to multidisciplinary researchers with an ENG focus. The major sessions of the Workshop were to include presentations on proposal writing, mock panels, and networking.

The Workshop was designed to assist faculty develop competitive NSF CAREER proposals and learn grant writing skills that will serve them throughout their careers. The Workshop was also to provide a great networking opportunity for research-focused faculty from across the country.  

Over 600 junior faculty (628) applied for the 300 slots available.  

Applications were encouraged from non-R1 institutions and faculty who identify themselves as from underrepresented groups.  The Workshop Committee also gave priority to applicants who had not previously attended a CAREER workshop, were from EPSCoR states and those who were three plus years into their academic careers. 

Due to coronavirus pandemic, the in-person workshop was rescheduled as a virtual event. Knowinnovation was hired to assist with the transforming the Workshop to a virtual conference.  The Workshop was originally planned for 1-1/2 days.  The workshop was scheduled to begin with a networking session on the evening prior of March 31, 2020.  The virtual workshop took place April 1- 2, 2020.  The networking session planned prior to the opening of the Workshop was rescheduled to take place over the lunch hour of Day 1 of the Workshop. 

One of the highlights of the Workshop was the mock NSF review panel. 

Participants were divided into 36 virtual panels.  Seventy-two current and former NSF Program Directors volunteered to facilitate the panels.  Six previously submitted CAREER proposals were volunteered and reviewed on the panels.  Three funded and three non-funded NSF ENG CAREER proposals were reviewed on each panel.  Workshop participants reviewed and critiqued past successful and unsuccessful NSF CAREER proposals. 

Participants were asked to review and rate the proposals prior to the Workshop.  At the panel each of the six proposals were be placed in a funding category and ranked.  The results from each panel were compared and discussed.

The participants noted the panels provided insight into the dynamics of the panel review process.

Tim Anderson, former Dean of Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst provided a Plenary Session titled "Life as an Assistant Professor - Tips to Tenure". 

At the end of the two-day workshop, participants were asked to complete an online evaluation survey. A total of 209 responses were recorded, or a 69.7% response rate. Individuals were allowed to skip questions they did not want to answer. The majority of respondents (71.29%) had never submitted a CAREER proposal to the National Science Foundation and 70.1% intend to submit a CAREER proposal this year.

The workshop was rated very positively: 95.12% agreed that the workshop was valuable and 92.68% would recommend it to a friend

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2021
Modified by: Rosemarie Wesson
